lesson.name: Lesson 7.1 Teacher Guide: Patterns of Change

page.title: 7.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students encounter a situation where a quantity increases and then decreases. They don’t yet have a name for this new pattern of change, but they recognize that it is neither linear nor exponential and that the graph is unlike the graph of an exponential function.

Students make sense of this new kind of relationship in a geometric context and describe it in concrete and qualitative ways. Though some students may choose to represent the relationships with calculations or with expressions, these are not required or emphasized in the lesson. Students will have many opportunities to reason symbolically about quadratic patterns in upcoming lessons.

Technology isn’t required for this lesson, but there are opportunities for students to choose to use appropriate tools to solve problems, so consider making technology available.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Describe (orally and in writing) a relationship that increases and then decreases when represented by a graph.
  • Given an interesting context, create drawings, tables, and graphs that represent a quadratic relationship.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Create drawings, tables, and graphs that represent the area of a garden.
  • Recognize a situation represented by a graph that increases and then decreases.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry.

Foundational: Lesson provides foundational content necessary for students to be able to perform this TEKS in later lessons.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 7.1.1: Noticing New Patterns of Change
  • 7.1.2: The Relationship Between Length and Area
    • 7.1.2: Self Check
    • 7.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.1.3: Plotting Measurements
    • 7.1.3: Self Check
    • 7.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.1.4: The Input and Output of a Function

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 7.1.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Graph paper
  • Calculators

Required Preparation

Graph paper is optional for the activity “The Relationship Between Length and Area.”

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • input
  • output
  • area
  • perimeter
  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their proactivity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • The Adaptability Advantage
  • Unrecognized Strengths

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Proactivity from Character Lab.

page.title: 7.1.1: Noticing New Patterns of Change
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm up encourages students to notice a new pattern of change (quadratic) by contrasting it with two familiar patterns (linear and exponential). In the table showing a quadratic relationship, students are not expected to recognize how the input and output values are related. This prompt gives students opportunities to see and make use of structure. The specific structure they might notice is that the output values don’t change by equal amounts or equal factors over equal intervals and that the output values increase and then decrease.

Student Activity

Look at the patterns in the three tables. What do you notice? What do you wonder?

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

0

2

5

3

10

4

15

5

20

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

3

2

6

3

12

4

24

5

48

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

8

2

11

3

10

4

5

5

–4


Answer:

Things you may notice:

  • The \(x\)-values are \(1\), \(2\), \(3\), \(4\), and \(5\) in all three tables.
  • In the first two tables, the \(y\)-values increase, while in the third table, they increase and then decrease.
  • The \(y\)-values in the first table are all multiples of \(5\), and they grow linearly. In the second table, the \(y\)-values grow by a factor of \(2\) each time \(x\) increases by \(1\). In the third table, there isn’t an obvious pattern in how the \(y\)-values change.

Things you may wonder:

  • Is there a rule for the relationship in the third table?
  • Will the \(y\)-values in the third table continue to decrease, or will they increase again at some point?
  • What would the third relationship look like if graphed?

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share what they noticed and wondered. Record and display their responses for all to see. After all responses have been recorded without commentary or editing, ask students, “Is there anything on these lists that you are wondering about?” Encourage students to respectfully disagree, ask for clarification, point out contradicting information, etc.

If no one wonders about the rule for the relationship in the third table or how the outputs are changing, ask students to consider these questions. Tell students that in this unit they will investigate relationships such the one shown in the third table.

page.title: 7.1.2: The Relationship Between Length and Area
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity gives students a concrete experience with a quadratic relationship in a familiar geometric context. Given a rectangle with a fixed perimeter, students experiment with how changes to one side of the rectangle affect its area. Along the way, they notice that as one length increases, the area does not continue to increase. Instead, at some point, it begins to decrease.

Students are not expected to write an equation such as \(ℓ \cdot (25−ℓ)\) for the area of the rectangle. At this point, informal observations on how the values are changing are sufficient. Students will have ample opportunities throughout this unit to examine the formal structure of quadratic relationships in depth.

As students work, encourage them to consider side lengths that are not whole numbers. Look for students who organize their work in different systematic ways and select them to share their work later.

Considering the relationship between the dimensions and area of a rectangle given a fixed perimeter requires students to reason abstractly and quantitatively. Making spreadsheet technology available gives students an opportunity to choose appropriate tools strategically.

Launch

Display a rectangle for all to see and label the sides with some lengths. Ask students to find the perimeter of the rectangle and the area of the region enclosed by this rectangle. Then, ask for the definitions of perimeter and area. Before beginning the activity, make sure students are clear about the distinction between the two measures—the perimeter is the distance all the way around a region, and the area is the number of unit squares that cover a region without gaps or overlaps.

Give students access to graph paper and tell students that they can use graph paper for the first question if they wish. Also provide access to calculators. Some students may benefit from using them to get to the interesting part of the task.

For the second question, some students may choose to create a spreadsheet to keep track of (and perhaps sort) the lengths, widths, and areas of the rectangle. Make a spreadsheet tool available, in case it is requested.

Student Activity

Noah has 50 meters of fencing to completely enclose a rectangular garden in the backyard.

  1. Draw some possible diagrams of Noah’s garden. Label the length and width of each rectangle.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

Your answers will vary. Did you consider organizing your lengths, widths, and areas into a table? For example:

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

5

20

100

10

15

150

12

13

156

12.5

12.5

156.25

18

7

126

20

5

100

24

1

24

  1. Find the length and width of a rectangle that would produce the largest possible area. Explain why you think that pair of length and width gives the largest possible area.

    Answer: When the length and width are each 12.5 meters, the area is the largest (156.25 square meters). A table shows that as the rectangular shape gets closer and closer to being a square, the area gets larger.

Anticipated Misconceptions

Some students may exclude a rectangle with side lengths 12.5 and 12.5 from their diagrams of Noah’s garden, possibly because they think a square is not a rectangle, or possibly because they only generate whole numbers. Emphasize that a square is a type of rectangle that happens to have four sides of equal length. Prompt them to think of the definition of a rectangle and explain why a square meets all the criteria for a rectangle.

Activity Synthesis

Display the work of a student who organized lengths, widths, and areas in a table. If no students did so, generate a table as a class. An example is shown here. (Pairs of length and area values will be needed in the next activity.)

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

5

20

100

10

15

150

12

13

156

12.5

12.5

156.25

18

7

126

20

5

100

24

1

24

Discuss with students:

  • “What do you notice about the relationship between the length and the width?” (They add up to 25. Each time the length increases by 1, the width decreases by 1. The relationship is linear.)
  • “What do you notice about the relationship between the length and the area?” (As the length increases from 1 to 24, the area increases and then decreases. The relationship is not linear.)

Ask students to describe the rectangle they found to have the largest area and how they went about finding it. It is likely that many students will say that it has side lengths of 12 and 13 since these are the whole-number values that produce the greatest area. If no students tried 12.5 and 12.5, ask them to compute this area.

Solicit some ideas from students on how the area is related to the length. Ask questions such as:

  • “How do we know if 12.5 and 12.5 would indeed produce the greatest area?”
  • “Do you think going from 5 to 8 meters in length would produce a rectangle with a greater area? What about going from 15 to 18? Why or why not?”

Tell students that we’ll try to get a better idea of what’s happening between the side lengths and the area of the rectangle by plotting some points in the next activity, “Plotting Measurements.”

7.1.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Sonya has 70 meters of fencing to surround a rectangular garden. What is the largest possible area that can be enclosed, in square meters?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

17.5

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the measurement of the length and the width for the largest possible area. The answer is 306.25.

35

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the sum of the width and length of the rectangle with the largest possible area. The answer is 306.25.

306.25

That’s correct! Check yourself: A square has the largest possible area with a length of 17.5 and a width of 17.5. Area of a rectangle is length times width.

1225

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the result of a length of 35 and width of 35. This would require 140 meters of fencing. The answer is 306.25.

7.1.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Largest Possible Area

Tyrel is enclosing a grassy area for his goats. He has 80 feet of fencing and wants to make a rectangular enclosed area. What are the dimensions of the enclosure with the largest possible area?

First, make a table with possible length and width dimensions and their areas. Remember, each \(2l+2w=80\) and \(A=lw\).

Length 

Width

Area

5

35

175

10

30

300

15

25

375

20

20

400

25

15

375

30

10

300

35

5

175

Notice that the closer the rectangle is to a square, the larger the area.

The largest area occurs when the length and width are both 20 feet for an area of 400 square feet.

Try It: Largest Possible Area

Elena has 100 feet of fencing to make a rectangular pen for her cow. What is the largest possible area she can make with this amount of fencing?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the largest possible area:

Make a table with possible dimensions:

Length

Width

Area

10

40

80

20

30

600

25

25

625

30

20

600

40

10

80

Notice the closer you are to a square, the larger the area.

The largest possible area is 625 square feet.

page.title: 7.1.3: Plotting Measurements
page.contents:
Activity (10 minutes)

In this activity, students plot the points that represent the relationship between a side length and the area of a rectangle with a perimeter of 50 meters. They encounter a graph where as one quantity increases, a second quantity increases and then decreases. Making sense of the graph in context helps them see why it is reasonable to expect the second quantity to decrease after a certain point.

As students work, look for those whose graphs include enough points to hint at a quadratic shape. Also, monitor for those who can articulate why \((1, 25)\) cannot represent the length and area of the garden. Invite them to share their work later.

Making graphing technology available gives students an opportunity to choose appropriate tools strategically.

Launch

Keep a table from the previous activity displayed. Students will have the example table from the previous activity in their lesson for use if needed. If students created their own table, encourage them to use the values in their table.

If students used a spreadsheet tool to organize the lengths and areas for the earlier activity, they may choose to use graphing technology to plot the data.

Student Activity

  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Plot some values for the length and area of the garden with perimeter 50 meters on the coordinate plane.

Use your table, or here is a sample table of values if you need one:

Values for a Rectangular Garden with a Perimeter of 50 Meters

Length (meters)

Area (square meters)

5

100

10

150

12

156

12.5

156.25

18

126

20

100

24

24

Be sure to label your axes. Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

  1. What do you notice about how the plotted points increase and decrease?

    Answer: At first, the area grows as the length increases, but then it decreases. Also, the area increases more and more slowly as the length increases.
  1. The points \((3, 66)\) and \((22, 66)\) each represent the length and area of the garden. Plot these two points on a coordinate plane, if you haven’t already done so. What do these points mean in this situation?

    Answer: The point \((3, 66)\) means that if the length of the garden is 3 meters, then the area is 66 square meters. This is right because the width is 22 meters and \(3 \cdot 22=66\). The point \((22, 66)\) means that the length of the garden is 22 meters, so its width is 3 meters, and the area is again 66 square meters.
  1. Could the point \((1, 25)\) represent the length and area of the garden?

    Answer: The point \((1, 25)\) cannot represent the length and area of the garden. If the length of the garden is 1 meter, the width would be 24 meters, so the area is 24 square meters, not 25 square meters.

Video: The Meaning of Points on a Graph

Watch the following video to learn more about the meaning of points on a graph.



Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?
  1. What happens to the area when you interchange the length and width? For example, compare the areas of a rectangle of length 11 meters and width 14 meters with a rectangle of length 14 meters and width 11 meters.

    Answer: The area stays the same if the length and width are interchanged because the area is the product of the length and the width.
  1. What patterns would you notice if you were to plot more length and area pairs on the graph?

    Answer: Many of the areas would come with two different pairs: for example, 100 comes from the pair \((5, 100)\) and also from the pair \((20, 100)\) because a rectangle with length 5 meters and width 20 meters is the same as a rectangle with length 20 meters and width 5 meters. Using a different length and corresponding width, the 156 comes from the pair \((12, 156)\) and also from the pair \((13, 156)\). The points on the graph would have reflectional symmetry about the line \(x=12.5\).

Activity Synthesis

Select a student to present their graph or display a graph with some points already plotted and amend it with additional points students provide. Discuss with students:

  • “Is the graph linear? Is it exponential?” (It is neither.)
  • “If we plot a bunch more points—say for every whole-number length between 0 and 25—what do you think the graph would look like?” (Possible predictions: A stretched out upside-down U, or an arch. A line with a positive slope that then turns into one with a negative slope. A curve. Some students might even recall the term parabola.)
  • “How can we tell whether \((1, 25)\) represents the length and area of the garden?” (By multiplying 1 and 24 (if the length is 1, the width is 24) to see if it gives 25. Because 1 times 24 is 24, \((1, 25)\) does not represent the length and area.)
  • “Can we tell if a point represents the length and area of the garden simply by plotting it on the graph? For example, does \((1.5, 200)\) represent the length and area? What about \((23, 60)\)?” (It depends. If a point is far away from other points (for example, \((1.5, 200)\)), we can probably tell it does not. If it seems to belong with the general trend of the other points, we may need to check if the input times the width equals the output value.)

Tell students that this unit will focus on functions like the one relating the length and area of the garden. The output of the functions may both increase and decrease, so we know they are neither linear nor exponential, but they also don’t change in a random way.

7.1.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

The graph below shows a rectangle’s side length and its area. What is true about the point \((3, 21)\)?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

The width of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\)-coordinate represents the length, not the width. The answer is the length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

The length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

That’s correct! Check yourself: The \(x\)-axis represents the side length, which would be the \(x\)-coordinate of 3 meters.

It is not possible to find the width of the rectangle when the length is 3 meters.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Working backward, the width would be 7 meters. The answer is the length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

The area of the rectangle is 3 square meters.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\)-coordinate represents the length, not the area. The answer is the length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

7.1.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Determining the Meaning of a Point on a Graph

The graph below shows the relationship between a rectangle’s side length and area.

What does the point \((7, 28)\) mean in the situation?

The \(x\)-axis represents the length of the rectangle in inches. So, when \(x=7\), the rectangle has a side length of 7 inches.

The \(y\)-axis represents the area of the rectangles. So, when \(y=28\), the rectangle has an area of 28 square inches.

This also means the rectangle has a width of 4 inches since \(7 \times 4=28\).

Try It: Determining the Meaning of a Point on a Graph

Using the same graph above, determine the meaning of the point \((3, 24)\) and the width of the rectangle.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to determine the meaning of the point \((3, 24)\) and the width of the rectangle:

Since the \(x\)-axis is the length of the rectangle in inches, \(x=3\) represents the length of the rectangle is 3 inches. Since the \(y\)-axis represents the area in square inches, the area of the rectangle is 24 square inches.

This means the width of the rectangle must be 8 inches since \(3 \times 8 = 24\).

page.title: 7.1.4: The Input and Output of a Function
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

A rectangular yard is enclosed by 100 meters of fencing. The table shows some possible values for the length and width of the yard.

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

10

40

400

20

30

25

25

625

35

15

525

40

  1. Complete the table with the missing values.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

10

40

400

20

30

600

25

25

625

35

15

525

40

10

400

The missing value in the second row is 600. The missing values in the last row are 10 and 400.

  1. If the values for length and area are plotted, what would the graph look like?

    Answer: The points would form a stretched out upside-down U shape, or an arch.
  1. How is the relationship between the length and the area of the rectangle different from other kinds of relationships we’ve seen before?

    Answer: As one quantity increases, the other quantity first increases and then decreases, instead of always increasing or always decreasing.

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 7.1.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here are a few pairs of positive numbers whose sum is 50.

Row

First number

Second number

Product

a

1

49

b

2

48

c

10

40

    1. Find the product in Row a.

ANSWER: 49

    1. Find the product in Row b.

ANSWER: 96

    1. Find the product in Row c.

ANSWER: 400

Use the following table to answer questions 2–5.

Here are some lengths and widths of a rectangle whose perimeter is 20 meters.

Row

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

a

1

9

b

3

7

c

5

d

7

e

9

  1. Complete the Width column of the table.

    1. Width in Row c

ANSWER: 5

    1. Width in Row d

ANSWER: 3

    1. Width in Row e

ANSWER: 1

  1. Complete the Area column of the table. What do you notice about the areas?

 

    1. Area in Row a

ANSWER: 9

    1. Area in Row b

ANSWER: 21

    1. Area in Row c

ANSWER: 25

    1. Area in Row d

ANSWER: 21

    1. Area in Row e

ANSWER: 9

  1. Without calculating, predict whether the area of the rectangle will be greater than or less than 25 square meters if the length is 5.25 meters.
    • greater than
    • less than

ANSWER: less than

  1. Plot the points for length and area from your table. Do the values change in a linear way? Do they change in an exponential way?
    • linear
    • exponential
    • linear and exponential
    • not linear and not exponential

ANSWER: not linear and not exponential

Use the following to answer questions 6–8.

Copies of a book are arranged in a stack. Each copy of a book is 2.1 cm thick.

Row

Copies of book

Stack height in cm

a

0

b

1

c

2

d

3

e

4

  1. Complete the table.
    1. Stack height in Row a

ANSWER: 0

    1. Stack height in Row b

ANSWER: 2.1

    1. Stack height in Row c

ANSWER: 4.2

    1. Stack height in Row d

ANSWER: 6.3

    1. Stack height in Row e

ANSWER: 8.4

  1. What is the difference in the height of the stack of books when a new copy of the book is added?

ANSWER: 2.1

  1. How high is a stack of \(b\) books, in centimeters?
    • \((2.1)b\)
    • \(2.1 +b\)
    • \(2.1(b-1)\)
    • \(2.1^b\)

ANSWER: \((2.1)b\)

page.title: 7.1.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Invite students to reflect on how the relationship between the side lengths and the area of a rectangle differs from other relationships they’ve seen. Consider asking students to comment on:

  • the values in the table relating the length and the area of the rectangle
  • the graph representing the length–area relationship
  • the rule that relates the input and output of the function

It is not essential that students frame their observations in precise ways at this point. Their capacity to do so will be developed in the coming lessons.
